;; Though the HW spelling is revised, the entry needs to be split as 3 AND grouped entries (iłā-dadha, iḍā-dadha, and ilā-dadha).
;; Also the accent change is to be noted.
;; Thus the entries would be as under-
;; <Ls>28698<pc>164,3<k1>???dadha<k2>iłā—dadha<e>3	<s>iłā—dadha</s>	¦ <lex>n.</lex> <ab>N.</ab> of a particular <s1 slp1="izwy-ayana">Iṣṭy-ayana</s1> or sacrificial observance, <ls>AitBr.</ls>; <ls>ĀśvŚr.</ls> <info n="rev" pc="1320,3"/><info lex="n"/>	<LEND>
;; The character | (the slp1 transliteration for ł) has some issue in the display and searching criteria, as identified elsewhere (MWS issue #88 ) and is yet to be resolved.
;; Hence marked it as ??? in the <k1> field, to draw the attention to the issue.
;; <Ls>28698.1<pc>164,3<k1>iḍādadha<k2>iḍā—dadha<e>3	<s>iḍā—dadha</s>	¦ <lex>n.</lex> <ab>N.</ab> of a particular <s1 slp1="izwy-ayana">Iṣṭy-ayana</s1> or sacrificial observance, <ls>AitBr.</ls>; <ls>ĀśvŚr.</ls> <info n="rev" pc="1320,3"/><info lex="n"/>	<LEND>

<L>28747<pc>165,1<k1>iti<k2>íti<h>2<e>1	<hom>2.</hom> <s>íti</s>	¦ <lex>ind.</lex> (<ab>fr.</ab> pronominal base 3. <s>i</s>), in this manner, thus (in its original signification <s>íti</s> refers to something that has been said or thought, or lays stress on what precedes;$in the <s1 slp1="brAhmaRa">Brāhmaṇa</s1>s it is often equivalent to ‘as you know’, reminding the hearer or reader of certain customs, conditions, &c. supposed to be known to him). In quotations of every kind <s>íti</s> means that the preceding words are the very words which some person has or might have spoken, and placed thus at the end of a speech it serves the purpose of inverted commas (<s>íty uktvā</s>, having so said;$<s>íti kṛtvā</s>, having so considered, having so decided). It may often have reference merely to what is passing in the mind <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>bālo 'pi nā<srs/>vamantavyo manuṣya íti bhūmipaḥ</s>, a king, though a child, is not to be despised, saying to one's self, ‘he is a mortal’, (<ls>Gr. 928.</ls>) In <ab>dram.</ab> <s>íti tathā karoti</s> means ‘after these words he acts thus.’ <div n="p"/>Sometimes <s>íti</s> is used to include under one head a number of separate objects aggregated together (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ijyā<srs/>dhyayanadānāni tapaḥ satyaṃ kṣamā damaḥ . alobha íti mārgo 'yam</s>, ‘sacrificing, studying, liberality, penance, truth, patience, self-restraint, absence of desire’, this course of conduct, &c.) <div n="p"/><s>íti</s> is sometimes followed by <s>evam</s>, <s>iva</s>, or a demonstrative pronoun pleonastically (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tām brūyād bhavatī<srs/>ty evam</s>, her he may call ‘lady’, thus). <div n="p"/><s>íti</s> may form an adverbial compound with the name of an author (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>íti-pāṇini</s>, thus according to <s1 slp1="pARini">Pāṇini</s1>). It may also express the act of calling attention (lo! behold!) It may have some other significations <ab>e.g.</ab> something additional (as in <s>ítyādi</s>, et caetera), order, arrangement specific or distinctive, and identity. It is used by native commentators after quoting a rule to express ‘according to such a rule’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>anudāttaṅita íty ātmanepadam bhavati</s>, according to the rule of <s1 slp1="pARini">Pāṇini</s1>, <ls> i, 3, 12</ls>, the <s1 slp1="Atmane-pada">Ātmane-pada</s1> takes place). <div n="p"/> <s>kim íti</s> = <s>kim</s>, wherefore, why? (In the <s1 slp1="SatapaTa-brAhmaRa">Śatapatha-brāhmaṇa</s1> <s>ti</s> occurs for <s>íti</s>;$<ab>cf.</ab> <ns>Prākṛt</ns> <i>ti</i> and <i>tti</i>.)<info lex="ind"/>	<LEND>
;; । character (devanagari danda) missed here.

<L>28800.1<pc>165,2<k1>id<k2>íd<e>1A	¦ indeed, assuredly (especially, in strengthening an antithesis, <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>yáthā váśanti devā́s táthé<srs/>d asat</s>, as the gods wish it, thus indeed it will be, <ls>RV. viii, 28, 4</ls>; <s>dípsanta íd ripávo nā́<srs/>ha debhuḥ</s>, the enemies wishing indeed to hurt were in nowise able to hurt, <ls>RV. i, 147, 3</ls>). <s>id</s> is often added to words expressing excess or exclusion (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>viśva it</s>, every one indeed; <s>śaśvad it</s>, constantly indeed; <s>eka it</s>, one only). At the beginning of sentences it often adds emphasis to pronouns, prepositions, particles (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tvam it</s>, thou indeed; <s>yadi it</s>, if indeed, &c.) <s>id</s> occurs often in the <s1 slp1="fg">Ṛg</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1> and <s1 slp1="aTarva">Atharva</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1>, seldom in the <s1 slp1="brAhmaRa">Brāhmaṇa</s1>s, and its place is taken in classical <ns>Sanskṛt</ns> by <s>eva</s> and other particles.<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>28801<pc>165,2<k1>idam<k2>idám<h>1<e>1	<s>idám</s> <hom>1</hom>	¦ <s>ayám</s>, <s>iyám</s>, <s>idám</s> (<ab>fr.</ab> <s>id</s>, <ls>Uṇ. iv, 156</ls>;$<ab>g.</ab> <s>sarvā<srs/>di</s>, <ls>Pāṇ. 1-1, 27</ls>;$<ls>Vop.</ls>;$a kind of neut. of the <ab>pronom.</ab> base 3. <s>i</s> with <s>am</s> [<ab>cf.</ab> <ab>Lat.</ab> <etym>is</etym>, <etym>ea</etym>, <etym>id</etym>, and <etym>idem</etym>];$the regular forms are partly derived from the <ab>pronom.</ab> base <s>a</s>;$See <ab>Gr.</ab> 224;$the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> exhibits various irregular formations <ab>e.g.</ab> <ab>fr.</ab> <ab>pronom.</ab> base <s>a</s>, an inst. <s>enā́</s>, <s>ayā́</s> [used in general adverbially], and <ab>gen.</ab> <ab>loc.</ab> <ab>du.</ab> <s>ayós</s>, and perhaps also <s>avós</s>, in <ls>RV. vi, 67, 11;$vii, 67, 4;$x, 132, 5</ls> [<ls>BRD.</ls>];$<ab>fr.</ab> the base <s>ima</s>, a <ab>gen.</ab> <ab>sing.</ab> <s>imásya</s>, only, <ls>RV.</ls>;$the <ls>RV.</ls> has in a few instances the irregular accentuation <s>ásmai</s>, <ls>v, 39, 5,</ls> &c.;$<s>ásya</s>, <ls>iv, 15, 5,</ls> &c.;$<s>ā́bhis</s>, <ls>vi, 25, 2,</ls> &c. : the forms derived <ab>fr.</ab> <s>a</s> are used enclitically if they take the place of the third personal pronoun, do not stand at the beginning of a verse or period, and have no peculiar stress laid upon them), this, this here, referring to something near the speaker<info lexcat="LEXID=pron,STEM=idam"/>	<LEND>

<L>28801.2<pc>165,2<k1>idam<k2>idám<e>1A	¦ (opposed to <s>adas</s> <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ayaṃ lokaḥ</s> or <s>idaṃ viśvam</s> or <s>idaṃ sarvam</s>, this earthly world, this universe; <s>ayam agniḥ</s>, this fire which burns on the earth; but <s>asāv agniḥ</s>, that fire in the sky, <ab>i.e.</ab> the lightning: so also <s>idam</s> or <s>iyam</s> alone sometimes signifies ‘this earth’; <s>ime smaḥ</s>, here we are.) <s>idam</s> often refers to something immediately following, whereas <s>etad</s> points to what precedes (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>śrutvai<srs/>tad idam ūcuḥ</s>, having heard that they said this). <s>idam</s> occurs connected with <s>yad</s>, <s>tad</s>, <s>etad</s>, <s>kim</s>, and a personal pronoun, partly to point out anything more distinctly and emphatically, partly pleonastically (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tad idaṃ vākyam</s>, this speech here following <pb n="165,3"/>; <s>so 'yaṃ vidūṣakaḥ</s>, this <s1 slp1="vidUzaka">Vidūṣaka</s1> here). 	<LEND>

;; BEGIN
<L>29121.1<pc>167,1<k1>indraśatru<k2>índra—śatru<e>3B	<s>índra—śatru</s>	¦ <lex>m.</lex> ‘<s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>'s enemy (in this sense the accent is <s>indra-śatrú</s> <ab>cf.</ab> <ab>Introd.</ab> <ab>p.</ab> xviii)’, <ab>N.</ab> of <s1 slp1="prahlAda">Prahlāda</s1>, <ls>Ragh. vii, 32</ls>; <ls>BhP. vi, 9, 11</ls> (with both the meanings). <info n="rev" pc="1321,1"/><info lex="m"/>	<LEND>
;; R(1321,1) -śatru (p. 167, col. 1), for (as) read (us) and after Indra’s enemy add: in this sense the accent is Indra-śatrú (cf. Introd. p. xviii.)
;; As there is "NO place" for the braced word-endings in the present text (esp. for m. and n. genders), the rev. text "for (as) read (us)" has been left out. 
;; The initial cap. letter of Indra-śatrú (as in the revision page) is to be specially noted; thus this word calls for a <ns> or <slp1> marking, not a pure <s> marking. 
;; Leaving it to Jim to take a call on this.
;; Also the braced portion in the original text in all the comp. words (28945-29157: a whopping lot of 200+ entries!!) under this indra HW needs attention- some are explicitly marked with accent mark and some are not marked, indicating that the front part of those "not explicitly marked" comp. words might need to have the accent mark removed.
;; As mentioned by MW himself in the Introd. pages, this accent marking has a very significant role in the Pāṇinian system (rather in any "pure Sanskrit system"); and we have to be careful in handling those markings in a diligent manner.
;; Again, leaving it to Jim to take a call on this.
;; END

<L>29223<pc>167,2<k1>indriya<k2>indriyá<e>2B	¦ the number five as symbolical of the five senses. (In addition to the five organs of perception, <s>buddhī<srs/>ndriyāṇi</s> or <s>jñāne<srs/>ndriyāṇi</s>, <ab>i.e.</ab> eye, ear, nose, tongue, and skin, the <ns>Hindūs</ns> enumerate five organs of action, <s>karme<srs/>ndriyāṇi</s> <ab>i.e.</ab> larynx, hand, foot, anus, and parts of generation;$between these ten organs and the soul or <s>ātman</s> stands <s>manas</s> or mind, considered as an eleventh organ;$in the <s1 slp1="vedAnta">Vedānta</s1>, <s>manas</s>, <s>buddhi</s>, <s>ahaṃkāra</s>, and <s>citta</s> form the four inner or internal organs, <s>antar-indriyāṇi</s>, so that according to this reckoning the organs are fourteen in number, each being presided over by its own ruler or <s>niyantṛ</s>;$thus, the eye by the Sun, the ear by the Quarters of the world, the nose by the two <s1 slp1="aSvin">Aśvin</s1>s, the tongue by <s1 slp1="pracetas">Pracetas</s1>, the skin by the Wind, the voice by Fire, the hand by <s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>, the foot by <s1 slp1="vizRu">Viṣṇu</s1>, the anus by <s1 slp1="mitra">Mitra</s1>, the parts of generation by <s1 slp1="prajApati">Prajāpati</s1>, manas by the Moon, <s1 slp1="budDi">buddhi</s1> by <s1 slp1="brahman">Brahman</s1>, <s1 slp1="ahaMkAra">ahaṃkāra</s1> by <s1 slp1="Siva">Śiva</s1>, citta by <s1 slp1="vizRu">Viṣṇu</s1> as <s1 slp1="acyuta">Acyuta</s1>;$in the <s1 slp1="nyAya">Nyāya</s1> philosophy each organ is connected with its own peculiar element, the nose with the Earth, the tongue with Water, the eye with Light or Fire, the skin with Air, the ear with Ether;$the <s1 slp1="jEna">Jaina</s1>s divide the whole creation into five sections, according to the number of organs attributed to each being.)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>

<L>30000.1<pc>171,3<k1>u<k2>u<e>1A	¦ (as a particle implying restriction and antithesis, generally after pronominals, prepositions, particles, and before <s>nu</s> and <s>su</s>, equivalent to) and, also, further; on the other hand (especially in connexion with a relative <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ya u</s>, he on the contrary who &c.)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>30000.2<pc>171,3<k1>u<k2>u<e>1A	¦ This particle may serve to give emphasis, like <s>id</s> and <s>eva</s>, especially after prepositions or demonstrative pronouns, in conjunction with <s>nu</s>, <s>vai</s>, <s>hi</s>, <s>cid</s>, &c. (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ayám u vām purutámo</s>... <s>johavīti</s> [<ls>RV. iii, 62, 2</ls>], this very person [your worshipper] invokes you &c.) It is especially used in the figure of speech called Anaphora, and particularly when the pronouns are repeated (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tám u stuṣa índram tám gṛṇīṣe</s> [<ls>RV. ii, 20, 4</ls>], him I praise, <s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>, him I sing). It may be used in drawing a conclusion, like the English ‘now’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tád u táthā ná kuryāt</s> [<ls>ŚBr. v, 2, 2, 3</ls>], that now he should not do in such a manner), and is frequently found in interrogative sentences (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ká u tác ciketa</s> [<ls>RV. i, 164, 48</ls>], who, I ask, should know that?)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>30000.3<pc>171,3<k1>u<k2>u<e>1A	¦ <s1 slp1="pARini">Pāṇini</s1> calls this particle <s>uñ</s> to distinguish it from the interrogative <s>u</s>. In the <s1 slp1="pada-pAWa">Pada-pāṭha</s1> it is written <s>ūm</s>.<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>30000.4<pc>171,3<k1>u<k2>u<e>1A	¦ In the classical language <s>u</s> occurs only after <s>atha</s>, <s>na</s>, and <s>kim</s>, with a slight modification of the sense, and often only as an expletive (See <s>kim</s>);<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>

<L>30689.1<pc>175,2<k1>uta<k2>utá<e>1A	¦ often used for the sake of emphasis, especially at the end of a line after <s>iti</s> or a verb (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>sarva-bhūtāni tam pārtha sadā paribhavanty uta</s>, all creatures, O king, certainly always despise him, <ls>MBh. iii, 1026</ls>), <ls>MBh.</ls>; <ls>Bhag.</ls> &c. (As an interrogative particle, generally at the beginning of the second or following part of a double interrogation) or, utrum - an (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>katham nirṇīyate kiṃ syān niṣkāraṇo bandhur uta viśvāsa-ghātakaḥ</s>, how can it be decided whether he be a friend without a motive or a violator of confidence? <ls>Hit.</ls>), <ls>Kum.</ls>; <ls>Kathās.</ls>; <ls>Bhartṛ.</ls>; <ls>Sāh.</ls> &c.<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>30689.2<pc>175,2<k1>uta<k2>utá<e>1A	¦ in this sense it may be strengthened by <s>āho</s> (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kaccit tvam asi mānuṣī utā<srs/>ho surā<srs/>ṅganā</s>, art thou a mortal woman or divine? <s1 slp1="nala">Nala</s1>), or by <s>āho-svit</s> (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>śālihotraḥ kiṃ nu syād utā<srs/>hosvid rājā nalaḥ</s>, can it be <s1 slp1="SAlihotra">Śālihotra</s1> or king <s1 slp1="nala">Nala</s1>?) Rarely <s>kim</s> is repeated before <s>uta</s> used in this sense (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kim nu svargāt prāptā tasyā rūpeṇa kimutā<srs/>nyā<srs/>gatā</s>, has she arrived from heaven or has another come in her form? <ls>Mṛcch.</ls>), <ls>Amar.</ls>;$<ls>MBh.</ls> &c. (As a particle of wishing, especially at the beginning of a sentence followed by a potential) would that! utinam! (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>utā<srs/>dhīyīta</s>, would that he would read!) (<s>uta</s> preceded by <s>kim</s>) on the contrary, how much more, how much less (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>samartho 'si sahasram api jetuṃ kimutai<srs/>kam</s>, thou art able to conquer even a thousand, how much more one, <ls>R.</ls>), <ls>Śak.</ls>;$<ls>Vikr.</ls>;$<ls>Ragh.</ls> &c. (<s>uta</s> preceded by <s>prati</s>) on the contrary, rather (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>eṣa pṛṣṭo 'smābhir na jalpati hanti praty-uta pāṣāṇaiḥ</s>, this one questioned by us does not speak, but rather throws stones at us), <ls>Kathās.</ls>;$<ls>Pañcat.</ls> &c.<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>

<L>34067<pc>194,3<k1>upa<k2>úpa<e>1	<s>úpa</s>	¦ <lex>ind.</lex> (a preposition or prefix to verbs and nouns, expressing) towards, near to (opposed to <s>apa</s>, away), by the side of, with, together with, under, down (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upa-√ gam</s>, to go near, undergo; <s>upa-gamana</s>, approaching; in the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> the verb has sometimes to be supplied from the context, and sometimes <s>upa</s> is placed after the verb to which it belongs, <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>āyayur upa</s> = <s>upā<srs/>yayuḥ</s>, they approached). (As unconnected with verbs and prefixed to nouns <s>upa</s> expresses) direction towards, nearness, contiguity in space, time, number, degree, resemblance, and relationship, but with the idea of subordination and inferiority (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upa-kaniṣṭhikā</s>, the finger next to the little finger; <s>upa-purāṇam</s>, a secondary or subordinate <s1 slp1="purARa">Purāṇa</s1>; <s>upa-daśa</s>, nearly ten)<info lex="ind"/>	<LEND>
<L>34067.1<pc>194,3<k1>upa<k2>úpa<e>1A	¦ sometimes forming with the nouns to which it is prefixed compound adverbs (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upa-mūlam</s>, at the root; <s>upa-pūrva-rātram</s>, towards the beginning of night; <s>upa-kūpe</s>, near a well) which lose their adverbial terminations if they are again compounded with nouns (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upakūpa-jalā<srs/>śaya</s>, a reservoir in the neighbourhood of a well)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
<L>34067.2<pc>194,3<k1>upa<k2>úpa<e>1A	¦ prefixed to proper names <s>upa</s> may express in classical literature ‘a younger brother’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upe<srs/>ndra</s>, ‘the younger brother of <s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>’), and in <ns>Buddhist</ns> literature ‘a son.’ (As a separable adverb <s>upa</s> rarely expresses) thereto, further, moreover (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tatro<srs/>pa brahma yo veda</s>, who further knows the <s1 slp1="brahman">Brahman</s1>), <ls>RV.</ls>; <ls>AV.</ls>; <ls>ŚBr.</ls>; <ls>PārGṛ.</ls> (As a separable preposition) near to, towards, in the direction of, under, below (with <ab>acc.</ab> <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>upa āśāḥ</s>, towards the regions)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>

;; R(1322,3) ṛjū́yat (fr. ṛjūya; read ṛjūyát)
;; As at many places, here also the accent change is not fully taken into account.
;; As ṛjū́yat is given in bold letters, it indicates the HW itself. The 'fr. ṛjūya' text appears to be the explanatory matter; and the later ṛjūyát appears to be meant for the braced text inside the body matter.
;; Hence my interpretation is to have the revised entry as under-
;; <Ls>38839<pc>225,3<k1>ṛjūyat<k2>ṛjū́yat<e>2	<s>ṛjū́yat</s>	¦ (<ab>fr.</ab> <s>ṛjūya</s>) <ab>Nom.</ab> <ab>P.</ab> (<ab>p.</ab> <s>ṛjūyát</s>) to walk straight-forward, be right or honest, <ls>RV.</ls> : <ab>Ā.</ab> (<ab>p.</ab> <s>ṛjūyámāna</s>) to tend straight upward, <ls>RV. x, 88, 9.</ls> <info n="rev" pc="1322,3"/><info verb="nom" cp="PĀ"/>	<LEND>

(<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tvam eva yantā nā<srs/>nyo 'sti pṛthivyām</s>, thou alone art a charioteer, no other is on earth, <ab>i.e.</ab> thou art the best charioteer, <ls>MBh. iii, 2825</ls>;$<s>tāvatīm eva rātrim</s>, just so long as a night;$<s>evam eva</s> or <s>tathai<srs/>va</s>, exactly so, in this manner only;$in the same manner as above;$<s>tenai<srs/>va mantreṇa</s>, with the same <s1 slp1="mantra">Mantra</s1> as above;$<s>apaḥ spṛṣṭvai<srs/>va</s>, by merely touching water;$<s>tān eva</s>, these very persons;$<s>na cirād eva</s>, in no long time at all;$<s>japyenai<srs/>va</s>, by sole repetition;$<s>abhuktvai<srs/>va</s>, even without having eaten;$<s>iti vadann eva</s>, at the very moment of saying so;$<s>sa jīvann eva</s>, he while still living, &c.), <ls>RV.</ls> &c., <ls>MBh.</ls> &c.<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>

<L>40704<pc>235,3<k1>om<k2>óm<e>1	<s>óm</s>	¦ <lex>ind.</lex> (√ <s>av</s>, <ls>Uṇ. i, 141</ls>;$originally <s>oṃ</s> = <s>āṃ</s>, which may be derived from <s>ā</s>, <ls>BRD.</ls>), a word of solemn affirmation and respectful assent, sometimes translated by ‘yes, verily, so be it’ (and in this sense compared with Amen;$it is placed at the commencement of most <ns>Hindū</ns> works, and as a sacred exclamation may be uttered [but not so as to be heard by ears profane] at the beginning and end of a reading of the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1>s or previously to any prayer;$it is also regarded as a particle of auspicious salutation [Hail!];$<s>om</s> appears first in the <s1 slp1="upanizad">Upaniṣad</s1>s as a mystic monosyllable, and is there set forth as the object of profound religious meditation, the highest spiritual efficacy being attributed not only to the whole word but also to the three sounds <s>a</s>, <s>u</s>, <s>m</s>, of which it consists;$in later times <s>om</s> is the mystic name for the <ns>Hindū</ns> triad, and represents the union of the three gods, <ab>viz.</ab> a (<s1 slp1="vizRu">Viṣṇu</s1>), <s>u</s> (<s1 slp1="Siva">Śiva</s1>), <s>m</s> (<s1 slp1="brahmA">Brahmā</s1>);$it may also be typical of the three <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1>s;$<s>om</s> is usually called <s>praṇava</s>, more rarely <s>akṣara</s>, or <s>ekākṣara</s>, and only in later times <s>oṃkāra</s>), <ls>VS.</ls>;$<ls>ŚBr.</ls>;$<ls>ChUp.</ls> &c.<info lex="ind"/>	<LEND>
<L>40704.1<pc>235,3<k1>om<k2>óm<e>1A	¦ (Buddhists place <s>om</s> at the beginning of their <s>vidyā ṣaḍakṣarī</s> or mystical formulary in six syllables [<ab>viz.</ab> <s>om maṇi padme hūṃ</s>]; according to, <ls>T.</ls> <s>om</s> may be used in the following senses: <s>praṇave</s>, <s>ārambhe</s>, <s>svīkāre</s>, <s>anumatau</s>, <s>apā<srs/>kṛtau</s>, <s>asvīkāre</s>, <s>maṅgale</s>, <s>śubhe</s>, <s>jñeye</s>, <s>brahmaṇi</s>; with preceding <s>a</s> or <s>ā</s>, the <s>o</s> of <s>om</s> does not form <s1 slp1="vfdDi">Vṛddhi</s1> (<s>au</s>), but <s1 slp1="guRa">Guṇa</s1> (<s>o</s>), <ls>Pāṇ. 6-1, 95.</ls>)<info lex="inh"/>	<LEND>
